description: Squares which can be rearranged into squares with the same number of digits.
comments: Squares that have some nontrivial permutation of digits which are also squares.There are 87 10-digit squares whose digits are a permutation of the digits 0..9. - T. D. Noe, Jan 23 2008
links: Gaurav Kumar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..523877 [This replaces an earlier b-file computed by T. D. Noe]
example: 144 is a square and so is 441, which is formed by rearranging the digits of 144.
mathematica: sndQ[n_]:=Module[{p=Select[FromDigits/@Permutations[IntegerDigits[n]], IntegerLength[ #] == IntegerLength[n]&]},Length[Select[ p,IntegerQ[ Sqrt[#]]&]]>1]; Select[Range[150]^2,sndQ] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Feb 18 2015 *)
prog: (Perl)#!/usr/bin/perl# change this to compute more terms:$max_digits = 5;# put the squares into a hash table; for example# 46 -> 64# 144 -> 144 441# 169 -> 169 196 961$max_i = sqrt(10 ** $max_digits);for $i (1..$max_i){    $i_sq = $i * $i;    $normalized = join('', sort(split(//, "$i_sq")));    $sq_hash{"$normalized"} .= "$i_sq ";}# find the hash entries with more than one squareforeach (values(%sq_hash)) { $nums .= $_ if (/ \d/); }# print the numbers in orderprint join(' ', sort( { $a <=> $b } split(' ',"$nums")));
author: _Erich Friedman_
extensions: Perl program from Jonathan Cross (jcross(AT)juggler.net), Oct 18 2003
